• The Dodd-Frank Act established the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) to focus on consumer protection in financial transactions.
    • The CFPB's structure, authorities, and the balance between consumer protection and credit availability are subject to debate.
    • Mortgage lending rules aim to protect consumers, but their impact on credit availability is also debated.
    • The $10 billion asset threshold for CFPB oversight of banks is another point of contention.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Extension Act of 2007 (P.L. 110-173) made changes to the nation's three major health programs:
    • Suspended the Medicare physician payment cut and provided a 0.5% increase in the physician fee schedule for the first six months of 2008
    • Provided SCHIP funding through March 2009 and redistributed unspent SCHIP funds to states with shortfalls
    • Extended various Medicare and Medicaid provisions, including:
        • Payments for certain providers and services
        • Policies related to Medicare Advantage plans and long-term care hospitals
    • Included offsets to pay for the provisions, such as reducing payments for the Medicare Advantage stabilization fund and modifying payment rates for certain services
    • Established MedPAC as a congressional agency
    • Provided funding for research and grants related to diabetes prevention and treatment
</summary>

<summary>
* House committees and subcommittees
    * Committees are required to adopt written rules that are not inconsistent with House rules
    * Committees must keep records of their activities and make them available to the public
    * Committees have the authority to conduct hearings, issue subpoenas, and take other actions to carry out their duties
        * Hearings and meetings must generally be open to the public, with exceptions for certain sensitive matters
        * Committees can set their own quorum requirements for conducting business
        * Committees must report measures they have approved to the House in a timely manner
    * Committees have oversight responsibilities to monitor the implementation of laws and programs within their jurisdictions
</summary>

<summary>
* The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a 10-member grouping of nations with a combined population of 580 million and an annual GDP of around $1.5 trillion.
    * ASEAN was established in 1967 to foster regional dialogue during the Cold War period.
    * ASEAN has grown into one of the world's largest regional fora, representing a strategically and economically important region.
* The Obama Administration is pursuing a policy of expanding and upgrading U.S. relations with Southeast Asia and ASEAN.
    * The Bush Administration's initiatives to develop ties with the region were perceived as narrowly focused on terrorism.
    * The Obama Administration has expressed an intent to pay greater attention to Southeast Asia and work with multilateral organizations like ASEAN.
* ASEAN remains, to a large degree, an informal organization with a lightly staffed Secretariat.
    * ASEAN operates on principles of consensus and non-interference in the internal affairs of members.
    * The new ASEAN Charter, which went into effect in 2007, may signal a greater willingness to discuss and comment on the internal affairs of the organization's members.
* ASEAN is at the center of several security- and trade-related groupings in the Asia-Pacific region.
    * The ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) was formed to facilitate dialogue on political and security matters in the region.
    * The East Asia Summit (EAS) represents an effort to balance China's influence in the region.
* ASEAN's trade and economic integration efforts include the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) and the goal of creating an ASEAN Economic Community by 2015.
    * ASEAN has concluded trade agreements with several countries, but the United States is the only major power in the region that has not agreed to a formal free trade agreement with ASEAN.
    * ASEAN has been actively promoting the creation of a larger, Asia-based free trade area, such as the East Asian Community (EAC).
</summary>

<summary>
* The "state sponsors of terrorism list" is mandated under Section 6(j) of the Export Administration Act of 1979, and it restricts trade, aid, and other benefits to countries on the list.
    * Cuba has been on the list since 1982, along with Iran, North Korea, Sudan, and Syria.
    * The list can be rescinded if the President certifies that the country has fundamentally changed its policies and no longer supports terrorism.
    * Congress can pass legislation to block the removal of a country from the list.
* Cuba was added to the list in 1982 due to its support for armed insurgencies and terrorist activities in Latin America and the Caribbean.
    * The Reagan administration cited Cuba's ties to groups like the M-19 guerrilla group in Colombia and its facilitation of the movement of people and weapons into the region.
    * Cuba has been accused of providing safe haven to members of foreign terrorist organizations and U.S. fugitives from justice.
    * Supporters of keeping Cuba on the list argue that it has a history of supporting terrorism, while critics view it as a holdover from the Cold War.
* The level of terrorist activity by countries on the list varies, and some suggest a tiered approach to sanctions based on the degree of support for terrorism.
    * Some argue for more flexibility in adding and removing countries from the list, while others believe the current system is sufficient.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) provides an alternative tax calculation on a broader tax base than the regular tax.
    • The AMT base is broader than the regular tax base, but it excludes certain provisions such as lower capital gains tax rates and the exclusion for tax-exempt bonds.
    • The AMT exemptions are not indexed to inflation, leading to an increase in the number of taxpayers covered by the AMT over time.
• The AMT is shifting from affecting primarily high-income individuals to reaching further down into the middle-income classes.
    • The share of taxpayers on the AMT in the middle-income brackets is expected to increase significantly.
    • The interaction between the AMT and tax cuts, such as the marriage penalty relief, can limit the benefits of the tax cuts for many taxpayers.
• The cost of correcting the AMT is significant, with indexing the AMT exemptions estimated to cost $13.9 billion by 2008.
    • Eliminating the credit limit provision and adding standard deductions would cost the U.S. Treasury $26 billion by 2009 and $96 billion for the period 1999-2009.
    • The AMT tax liability is projected to rise from $6.4 billion in 2001 to $38.2 billion in 2010 before considering the recent tax changes.
• There are different views on the role of the AMT, with some seeing it as a desirable alternative tax and others considering it an unnecessary complication.
    • Adjustments to the AMT, such as indexing the exemption levels and aligning it with regular tax changes, are complex and have no clear solutions.
    • The growth in the AMT has been a concern, and its importance increases with tax cuts, as not all taxpayers receive the full benefit of the tax cuts.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies (THUD) Appropriations Subcommittees are responsible for drafting bills to provide annual appropriations for the Department of Transportation (DOT) and the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD).
    • DOT is primarily a grant-making and regulatory organization, with the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) being the largest sub-agency.
    • HUD's programs are primarily designed to address housing problems faced by households with very low incomes or other special housing needs, including several rental assistance programs.
    • The THUD appropriations bill also funds a collection of related agencies, including the Access Board, the Federal Maritime Commission, and the Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation.
• The THUD bill is funded through regular annual appropriations, as well as advance appropriations and emergency appropriations.
    • DOT's budget is primarily in the form of contract authority, which is a type of mandatory budget authority.
    • Appropriators can offset a higher level of discretionary funding through rescissions and offsetting receipts and collections.
• The Trump Administration's FY2018 budget request for THUD was $106.65 billion, which was $9.7 billion less than the FY2017 level.
    • The House-passed bill would provide $115.3 billion for THUD, while the Senate-reported bill would provide $119.1 billion.
    • The House bill would result in a reduction of roughly 3% in real THUD funding, while the Senate bill would result in a slight increase in real funding, compared to FY2017.
</summary>

<summary>
* U.S.-India "global partnership" and cooperation on various issues
    * India has traditionally maintained positive relations with Iran, which has caused concerns in the U.S.
* India's relations with Iran
    * India has a "strategic partnership" with Iran, with strong historical and civilizational ties
    * India has continued to strengthen its ties with Iran, despite U.S. pressure to isolate Iran
* India's IAEA votes on Iran's nuclear program
    * India has faced criticism for voting with the U.S. on IAEA resolutions regarding Iran's nuclear program
    * India has rejected attempts to link its IAEA votes with the U.S.-India civil nuclear cooperation
* India-Iran defense and military relations
    * India and Iran have established defense and military cooperation, but it has not evolved into a strategic alliance
    * India has provided some technical assistance to Iran, which has led to U.S. sanctions on Indian entities
* India-Iran energy cooperation
    * India is a major importer of Iranian oil and is involved in various energy projects with Iran
    * The proposed Iran-India gas pipeline project has faced U.S. opposition
* India's role in Afghanistan
    * India and Iran have cooperated to support the U.S.-backed government in Afghanistan and prevent the return of the Taliban
</summary>

<summary>
• Overview of Milk Protein Concentrates (MPCs) and their use in the food industry
    • MPCs are derived from raw milk and used in various food products, animal feed, and industrial products
    • MPCs are manufactured through ultrafiltration, blending, or co-precipitation
    • MPCs have different protein levels and functional characteristics compared to nonfat dry milk
    • The U.S. produces very little casein or MPCs, leading to reliance on imports
• Concerns about MPC imports and proposed legislative actions
    • Dairy farmers and their supporters advocate for stricter import controls on MPCs to raise milk prices
    • Opponents argue that import restrictions would increase costs for food manufacturers and raise retail prices
    • Proposed legislation would establish tariff-rate quotas (TRQs) on MPC imports, leading to potential compensation negotiations with major suppliers under WTO rules
    • The potential impact of import restrictions on farm milk prices depends on the relationship between dairy product prices and government support levels
• Canada's actions to restrict MPC imports
    • Canada initiated GATT Article XXVIII negotiations to restrict imports of MPCs with 85% or more protein content
    • The TRQ does not apply to NAFTA countries and other countries with which Canada has free trade agreements
• Positions of industry groups
    • Dairy farmers and their organizations support legislation to limit MPC imports
    • Dairy product processors and manufacturers oppose more restrictions on dairy imports
</summary>

<summary>
* Serbia's political and economic transition since 2000
    * Defeat of Slobodan Milosevic's regime and transition to democracy
    * Challenges in EU integration due to Kosovo issue and economic crisis
    * Ongoing issues with corruption, organized crime, and regional tensions
* Serbia's relations with Kosovo and the EU
    * Negotiations on normalizing relations with Kosovo under EU mediation
    * Efforts to balance EU integration with non-recognition of Kosovo's independence
    * Gradual progress in EU accession process, but Kosovo issue remains a major obstacle
* U.S. relations with Serbia
    * Improved ties since 2000, but Kosovo issue continues to affect the relationship
    * U.S. support for Serbia's EU integration and normalization of relations with Kosovo
    * Ongoing cooperation in areas like military, counterterrorism, and economic reform
</summary>

<summary>
* The Supreme Court decided four search and seizure cases during its October 2012 term:
    * Florida v. Jardines: Whether a trained narcotics-detection dog's sniff at the front door of a suspected grow house is a Fourth Amendment search.
    * Florida v. Harris: Whether an alert by a trained drug-detection dog is sufficient to establish probable cause for a search of a vehicle.
    * Bailey v. United States: Whether the detention of an individual who has just left premises to be searched under warrant is permissible when the individual is detained out of view of the house as soon as possible.
    * Missouri v. McNeely: Whether the natural metabolization of alcohol in the bloodstream presents a per se exigency that justifies an exception to the Fourth Amendment's warrant requirement for nonconsensual blood testing in all drunk-driving cases.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Department of Energy's Office of Electricity Delivery and Energy Reliability (OE) supports electric grid modernization and resiliency through research and development, demonstration projects, partnerships, and emergency preparedness and response.
    * OE's mission is guided by the Quadrennial Technology Review and the Grid Modernization Multi-Year Program Plan, which aim to improve the reliability, affordability, and security of the electric grid.
    * OE's funding is primarily focused on research and development, with the remainder going towards planning and other operational areas.
    * OE's key programs include the Clean Energy Transmission and Reliability (CETR) program, the Smart Grid program, the Cybersecurity for Energy Delivery Systems (CEDS) program, and the Energy Storage program.
* The FY2017 budget request for OE sought to establish three new programs:
    * The Grid Institute, focused on transitioning innovative materials and production technologies to industry
    * The State Distribution-Level Reform program, to help states address distribution system challenges
    * The State Energy Assurance program, to improve state and local energy emergency planning and response capabilities.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Commemorative Works Act (CWA) of 1986 was enacted to guide the creation of memorials in the District of Columbia.
    * The CWA divides the District of Columbia and its environs into three sections for the placement of memorials: the Reserve, Area I, and Area II.
    * The CWA specifies requirements for military works and works commemorating events, individuals, or groups.
* The process for establishing a memorial in the Nation's Capital involves several entities, including:
    * The National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission, which advises on policy and procedures for establishing commemorative works.
    * The U.S. Commission of Fine Arts, which provides advice on the selection of models for statues, fountains, and monuments.
* The National Capital Planning Commission is responsible for providing guidance and approval at multiple steps of the monument and memorial creation process in the District of Columbia.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Senate Finance Committee approved the America's Healthy Future Act of 2009 on October 13, 2009.
    * The bill would restructure the private health insurance market, set minimum standards for health benefits, and provide financial assistance to certain individuals and small employers.
    * The bill would require individuals to maintain health insurance and certain employers to provide insurance or pay a tax.
* The bill would establish new federal standards for private health insurance plans, primarily affecting the individual and small group markets.
    * These standards would impose new requirements on states related to the allocation of insurance risk and modify the current state-based regulatory system.
    * The bill would require coverage for specified categories of benefits and prohibit plans from excluding coverage for pre-existing conditions or charging premiums based on health status.
* The bill would establish health insurance exchanges through which individuals and small businesses could obtain qualified health benefits plans (QHBPs).
    * Exchanges would not be insurers but would provide access to private plans in a comparable way.
    * Certain individuals with incomes below 400% of the federal poverty level could qualify for credits toward their premium costs and subsidies towards their cost-sharing.
* The bill would establish a program for states to provide a qualified basic health plan as an alternative to offering coverage through an exchange.
* The bill would provide incentives for the creation of health insurance co-operatives through the distribution of $6 billion in funding.
* The bill would impose excise taxes and annual fees on health insurers and limit the deductibility of executive compensation to help pay for the expanded health insurance coverage.
    * The bill would also modify tax-advantaged accounts and deductions used for health care spending and coverage.
</summary>

<summary>
* High Risk Health Insurance Pools
    * Established in 35 states to provide coverage for individuals with pre-existing conditions who cannot obtain or afford health insurance in the private market
    * Enroll a small percentage of the uninsured, around 200,000 individuals in 2008, due to their narrow focus
    * Offer coverage that is generally available in the private non-group market, with varying deductibles, cost-sharing, and exclusions for pre-existing conditions
    * Operate at a loss, with states using various funding sources to cover the losses, including assessments on insurers and federal grants
* Federal Grants to State High Risk Pools
    * Congress has provided funding to support the establishment and operation of state high risk pools since the 1990s
    * Grants include seed grants to establish new pools and operational grants to cover losses of existing pools
    * Funding levels have varied over the years, with the most recent appropriation of $55 million in 2010
    * The Affordable Care Act also established a temporary federal high risk pool program to provide coverage prior to 2014
</summary>

<summary>
* The Civil Reserve Air Fleet (CRAF) was created in 1951 to meet the nation's airlift needs in times of crisis.
    * CRAF has three main segments: international, national, and aeromedical evacuation.
    * CRAF has been formally activated on two separate occasions: during Operations Desert Shield/Storm and Operation Iraqi Freedom.
* CRAF presents benefits and opportunities for both the Department of Defense (DOD) and the U.S. airline industry.
    * CRAF is relatively inexpensive for DOD compared to procuring and maintaining a larger organic fleet.
* Recent legislation has addressed CRAF, including a comprehensive assessment, extension of the Aviation Insurance Program, and a study on the size and mix of the airlift force.
</summary>

<summary>
• The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is an agency in the U.S. Department of Commerce that serves as the executive branch's principal advisory office on domestic and international telecommunications and information technology policies.
    • NTIA frequently works with other executive branch agencies to develop and present the Administration's position on key policy matters.
    • NTIA represents the executive branch in both domestic and international telecommunications and information policy activities.
    • NTIA administers various grant programs, including the Broadband Technology Opportunities Program (BTOP) and the Public Safety Interoperable Communications (PSIC) grant program.
• NTIA plays a key role in federal spectrum management, acting as a facilitator and mediator in negotiations among federal agencies.
    • NTIA collaborates with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) on spectrum access, technology, and policy.
    • NTIA leads and participates in interagency efforts to develop Internet policy.
• NTIA's organizational structure includes several offices that handle different responsibilities.
    • The Office of Spectrum Management (OSM) formulates and establishes plans and policies for the effective, efficient, and equitable use of the spectrum.
    • The Office of Policy Analysis and Development (OPAD) supports NTIA's role as the principal adviser to the Executive Branch on telecommunications and information policies.
    • The Office of International Affairs (OIA) develops and implements policies to enhance U.S. companies' ability to compete globally in the information technology and communications sectors.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Energy Policy Act of 2005 was the first omnibus energy legislation enacted in more than a decade.
    • It provided federal jurisdiction over activities to support reliability of the U.S. bulk power system.
    • It required FERC to create a FERC-certified Electric Reliability Organization (ERO) to develop and enforce reliability standards.
    • It authorized the Secretary of Energy to designate congested areas and allowed FERC to issue construction permits.
• The Act also included provisions related to:
    • Third-party financing of transmission facilities
    • Encouraging deployment of advanced transmission technologies
    • Providing incentive payments for advanced power generation systems
    • Requiring open nondiscriminatory access to transmission facilities
• The Act repealed the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 (PUHCA) and made changes to the Federal Power Act.
    • It gave FERC access to books and records of holding companies and their affiliates.
    • It allowed state commissions to access the books and records of holding companies.
    • It retained FERC's authority to prevent cross-subsidization and ensure just and reasonable rates.
• The Act included provisions to improve electricity market transparency, prohibit market manipulation, and increase penalties for violations.
    • It authorized FERC to issue rules to provide timely information about wholesale electricity prices and transmission service.
    • It prohibited false reporting of information and the use of manipulative or deceptive devices in electricity markets.
    • It increased criminal and civil penalties for violations of the Federal Power Act.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Robinson-Patman Act (R-P) was enacted in 1936 to help small businesses compete with larger rivals, particularly in the grocery industry.
    * The act prohibits sellers in interstate commerce from charging different purchasers different prices for goods of "like grade and quality."
    * The act has several affirmative defenses, including "meeting competition," "cost justified," and the "nonprofit institutions" exemption.
    * The Supreme Court has provided significant interpretations of the scope of the nonprofit exemption, including limiting it to purchases for the hospital's own use and excluding purchases for retail competition.
    * Health maintenance organizations (HMOs) have been found to be eligible for the nonprofit exemption, as their basic function is to provide a complete range of health care services to their members.
* The Department of Justice and the Antitrust Modernization Commission have both criticized the Robinson-Patman Act, arguing that it has had the unintended effect of limiting discounting and causing higher prices for consumers.
    * Efforts to modify or repeal the act have been considered by Congress, but no legislation has been introduced.
    * The current economic climate may result in renewed efforts to change the statute, but the outcome is uncertain.
* The successful plaintiff in a Robinson-Patman Act case is not automatically entitled to damages in the amount of the unlawful price differential, as the plaintiff must show actual injury attributable to the antitrust violation.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Obama Administration has faced scrutiny over its use of enforcement discretion to limit or delay the enforcement of federal laws.
    * The Department of Justice has cited prosecutorial discretion to limit enforcement of the Controlled Substances Act in states that have legalized marijuana.
    * The Department of Homeland Security has used administrative enforcement discretion to defer deportation of certain undocumented immigrants.
    * The Administration has used enforcement discretion to delay enforcement of provisions of the Affordable Care Act.
* The Take Care Clause of the Constitution requires the President to faithfully execute the law, but the courts have generally deferred to executive enforcement discretion.
    * The courts have recognized prosecutorial discretion in the criminal context and administrative enforcement discretion in the civil context.
* Congress may be able to limit executive enforcement discretion through legislation, but the precise scope of Congress's authority remains unclear.
    * Congress may be able to set enforcement priorities, prohibit consideration of certain factors, or establish mandatory enforcement frameworks.
    * However, Congress cannot directly enforce the law or compel the executive to bring criminal prosecutions against specific individuals.
</summary>

<summary>
* Key Findings
    * The official U.S. poverty rate was 14.5% in 2013, a statistically significant drop from 15.0% in 2012.
    * The Supplemental Poverty Measure (SPM) provides a more comprehensive view of poverty, including the effects of government programs and necessary expenses.
    * The SPM paints a different picture of poverty, with higher rates among the elderly and lower rates among children compared to the official measure.
        * The SPM poverty rate for the elderly is 14.6%, compared to 9.5% under the official measure.
        * The SPM poverty rate for children is 16.4%, compared to 20.3% under the official measure.
        * The SPM captures the effects of in-kind benefits and necessary expenses, such as child care and medical costs, which significantly impact poverty rates.
        * The SPM's expanded definition of economic units also contributes to differences in poverty rates compared to the official measure.
</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. agricultural sector is heavily dependent on exports, which account for about 20% of total U.S. agricultural production.
    * The U.S. farm policy is subject to intense scrutiny for compliance with current WTO rules and its potential to affect future multilateral negotiations.
    * The U.S. is subject to a spending limit of $19.1 billion in amber box outlays under the WTO Agreement on Agriculture (AoA).
* The U.S. farm programs are also subject to the WTO Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures (SCM), which evaluates the market distortion of a program or policy in terms of its measurable market effects on international trade and/or market price.
    * The WTO's dispute settlement process can lead to the elimination, alteration, or amendment of U.S. farm programs that are found to be in violation of WTO rules.
    * The U.S. has never exceeded its AMS limit, with the closest approach being in 2000 when the U.S. notified a total AMS of $16.8 billion.
* The U.S. has notified various domestic policies to the WTO, including green box policies ($127.5 billion), blue box policies ($0), de minimis exclusions ($5.3 billion), and amber box policies ($6.9 billion).
    * The U.S. has not notified any payments under the blue box since 1995.
    * The U.S. has exempted a significant portion of its domestic support from the AMS limit through the de minimis exclusions.
</summary>

<summary>
• The campus-based student financial aid programs under the Higher Education Act of 1965 include the Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant (FSEOG) program, the Federal Work-Study (FWS) program, and the Federal Perkins Loan program.
    • These programs are considered "campus-based" because federal funds are awarded directly to institutions of higher education (IHEs) that administer the programs and provide institutional funds to match the federal funds.
    • The campus-based programs have come to play a relatively smaller role in the federal student aid effort, with the Direct Loan and Pell Grant programs accounting for the majority of federal student aid.
• As Congress considers reauthorization of the Higher Education Act, several issues related to the campus-based programs may be considered, including:
    • The extent to which the campus-based programs provide types of aid to students that are not provided via other postsecondary aid programs.
    • Whether the current formula for allocating funds to institutions is optimal.
    • The potential role of the campus-based aid programs in a redesigned federal aid system.
• Specific issues related to each campus-based program may also be considered, such as:
    • Whether FSEOG funds can be better targeted to low-income students.
    • Whether community service should continue to be an explicit purpose of the FWS program.
    • The wind-down of the Perkins Loan program and potential options for providing additional borrowing capacity to students.
</summary>

<summary>
* Alert systems for vulnerable missing adults are a recent but growing initiative, with 11 states identified as having active programs:
    * The systems were authorized either by law or executive order, with most states passing a law to create the alert system.
* Administration of the alert systems is a cooperative effort among state and local law enforcement agencies:
    * Six states have a lead state agency responsible for activating alerts, while five states have localized models where the local law enforcement agency activates the alerts.
* States have defined their target population for the alert systems differently, with some including age as a factor and others focusing on cognitive, physical, or developmental disabilities:
    * Verification of a cognitive impairment or other disability is often included as part of the state's criteria for activating an alert.
* States provided varying levels of detail about training for law enforcement agencies and the public on the use of the alert system:
    * Eight of the 11 states reported that training was provided to state and/or local enforcement agencies, and four of these also provided training or educational materials to the public and other stakeholders.
* The process for activating an alert varies across states, but generally begins with the local law enforcement agency taking a missing persons report:
    * States have defined common criteria for activating an alert, such as the person's status being unknown and their disappearance posing a credible threat to their health or safety.
* Most states have mechanisms in place for coordinating alerts with other states to recover individuals who were believed to have crossed state lines during their disappearance:
    * Several states indicated there was no additional cost to implement the alert system or that implementation costs were absorbed by the existing budget for the AMBER alert program or another program.
* Ten out of 11 states reported having used the alert system, with the number of alerts activated ranging from 1 to 82:
    * Most states were able to provide information about the outcomes of recovery efforts, with the majority reporting that individuals were found recovered, though almost every state reported at least one individual who was found deceased.
</summary>

<summary>
• The report describes and analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2017.
    • It compares the enacted FY2016 appropriations, the Obama Administration's FY2017 budget request, the Trump Administration's requests for additional funding, and the appropriations measures developed in response.
    • It provides additional informational resources, reports, and policy experts on DHS appropriations.
• The report discusses various budgetary concepts, including budget authority, obligations, outlays, discretionary and mandatory spending, offsetting collections, allocations, and adjustments to the discretionary spending caps.
    • The report notes that the DHS appropriations bill includes all annual appropriations provided for DHS, allocating resources to every departmental component.
    • The report explains the implementation of the Common Appropriations Structure (CAS) for DHS, which was introduced in FY2017.
• The report provides textual and tabular comparisons of FY2016 enacted and FY2017 requested and enacted appropriations for the department, organized by the five titles of the DHS appropriations act.
    • The report discusses the impact of the Budget Control Act on DHS appropriations, including the use of adjustments for disaster relief and overseas contingency operations.
</summary>

<summary>
* Water infrastructure systems are vulnerable to various types of terrorist attacks, including physical disruption, bioterrorism/chemical contamination, and cyber attacks.
    * The federal government has responsibility for only about 5% of the dams whose failure could result in loss of life or significant property damage, with the remaining dams belonging to state or local governments, utilities, and corporate or private owners.
    * Since the 9/11 attacks, water and wastewater utilities have taken various security measures, including conducting vulnerability assessments, implementing physical security enhancements, and coordinating with law enforcement and emergency response officials.
    * Congress has provided appropriations to federal agencies, such as the Bureau of Reclamation and the Army Corps of Engineers, to support security-related programs and activities to protect water infrastructure.
* Policymakers have considered various initiatives to address water infrastructure security, including enhancing physical security, improving communication and coordination, and supporting research.
    * A key issue is whether protective measures should focus on the largest water systems and facilities or on all, given the diverse ownership and limited federal control over the water infrastructure sector.
    * Another issue is the coordination and information-sharing among federal agencies, such as the Department of Homeland Security and the Environmental Protection Agency, in providing security to water utilities.
</summary>

<summary>
* The federal government provides support for career and technical education through the Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Technical Education Act of 1998 (Perkins III), which was reauthorized in 2006 as the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006 (Perkins IV).
    * Perkins IV authorizes "such sums as may be necessary" for FY2007-FY2012 and retains the overall purpose of the act, making only technical changes.
    * Perkins IV modifies the state allotment formula, accountability requirements, and sanctions, as well as the contents of state and local plans and the uses of funds.
* Perkins IV establishes six core indicators of performance at the secondary level and five at the postsecondary level, with a focus on academic achievement, technical skill attainment, and employment outcomes.
    * Eligible agencies and recipients must negotiate adjusted levels of performance for each core indicator and report annual progress, with sanctions for failing to meet at least 90% of the adjusted levels.
* Perkins IV requires eligible agencies to develop state plans covering a six-year period and eligible recipients to develop local plans, with new requirements related to academic and technical integration, career and technical programs of study, and professional development.
    * The tech-prep program remains a separate program, but eligible agencies can choose to combine tech-prep funds with their state grant funds.
* Perkins IV includes new provisions regarding the equitable participation of private school students and staff in career and technical education programs and professional development activities.
</summary>

<summary>
* The report discusses the major provisions of the federal estate, gift, and generation-skipping transfer taxes as they apply to transfers in 2014.
    * The federal estate and gift taxes are unified, utilizing the same rate structure and a lifetime transfer credit.
    * The generation-skipping transfer tax is a flat-rate tax applied to three different transfer events: a direct skip, a taxable termination, or a taxable distribution.
</summary>

<summary>
• Border and Transportation Security (BTS) is a critical function in protecting the American people from terrorists and their instruments of destruction.
    • Congress has taken various actions to address border security, including:
        • Broad efforts to understand the terrorist threat
        • Structural changes to provide a proper framework for action
        • Highly specific actions to protect against immediate threats
        • Interest in broader, more comprehensive approaches
• The Homeland Security Act of 2002 consolidated many federal agencies responsible for border and transportation security into the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).
    • DHS's Directorate of BTS is charged with securing the borders, territorial waters, terminals, waterways, and transportation systems of the United States.
• Current border security activities can be divided into people-related and goods-related programs.
    • People-related programs include pre-inspections, advance passenger manifests, and passenger pre-screening.
    • Goods-related programs include advance cargo manifests, the Container Security Initiative, and the Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism.
• Efforts to secure the border include pushing the border outwards, hardening the border through technology, making the border more accessible for legitimate travel and trade, strengthening the border through more effective use of intelligence, and engaging other actors in the enforcement effort.
    • Intelligence plays a critical role in border security by providing indications and warnings to DHS personnel.
</summary>

<summary>
• Cabo Verde is a small island nation with historical ties to the United States
    • It is considered a success story in Africa and an important U.S. partner in West Africa
    • Its strategic location makes it a transshipment point for Latin American cocaine bound for Europe
    • It has a strong democratic governance and high per capita income levels
• U.S.-Cabo Verdean cooperation focuses on counternarcotics efforts and development projects
    • The U.S. provides military training and equipment through the IMET program and the MCC
    • There is an Open Skies commercial aviation agreement and Cabo Verde is eligible for AGOA tariff preferences
    • However, its trade with the U.S. is minimal
• Cabo Verde's political system is democratic, with a multi-party system and regular elections
    • The MPD and PAICV parties have dominated politics since the transition to democracy in 1991
    • Expatriate voters play a significant role in national elections
    • The new MPD government has prioritized economic expansion, job growth, and poverty reduction
• Cabo Verde faces some rule of law and human rights challenges, but its record is better than most African countries
    • It is classified as a lower-middle-income economy with a high literacy rate and positive social indicators
    • Tourism has been a key driver of economic growth, but the country is seeking to diversify its trade and investment partnerships
    • Poverty remains a challenge, particularly in rural areas and among women and youth
</summary>

<summary>
• The return of security cooperation between the United States and New Zealand has forged a new security partnership between the two countries.
    • The Wellington Declaration of 2010 and the Washington Declaration of 2012 have consolidated the developing relationship and opened the way for further enhanced strategic dialogue and defense cooperation.
    • New Zealand's military commitment to Afghanistan and participation in exercises like RIMPAC have positively affected perceptions in Washington and underlined the value of partnering with New Zealand.
• New Zealand's foreign policy orientation has shifted over time, with its national identity and interests increasingly focused on the Asia-Pacific region.
    • New Zealand has a special relationship with the South Pacific and can play a key role as a partner to promote security, stability, and prosperity in the region.
    • New Zealand's economy has become increasingly linked to China, and the government promotes trade with China while being sensitive to anything that might disturb the nation's lucrative and growing trade relationship.
• There is a range of views in New Zealand on the rise of China, its implications for New Zealand, and the way New Zealand should position itself within the shifting geopolitical and trade dynamics of the region.
    • China's increasing presence and influence in the Pacific have raised concerns among some in New Zealand, while others see opportunities for Pacific Island countries to gain foreign assistance.
• The relationship between the United States and New Zealand is qualitatively deeper than those based only on common interests, as it is rooted in shared values and a common history.
    • Subtle differences in values can explain past differences in the relationship, and a more nuanced understanding of these areas of commonality and difference can inform future policy decisions.
</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. Constitution establishes two methods for the President to appoint officers: with the advice and consent of the Senate, or during the Recess of the Senate.
    * This has led to tension between the President and Congress, as seen with President Obama's difficulty in obtaining Senate confirmation for the Director of the CFPB and members of the NLRB.
    * President Obama made recess appointments for these positions in January 2012, during pro forma sessions of the Senate, which raised legal questions about the scope of the President's recess appointment power.
* The Recess Appointments Clause has been interpreted to encompass both inter- and intrasession recesses, but there is ambiguity around the minimum length of a recess required to trigger the President's power.
    * The use of pro forma sessions by the Senate to prevent a recess may impact the validity of the President's appointments.
    * A reviewing court would likely consider whether pro forma sessions constitute a "Recess of the Senate" for the purposes of the Recess Appointments Clause.
* The President's recess appointments also raise questions about the statutory authorities that the recess appointees may exercise.
    * The Consumer Financial Protection Act (CFP Act) provides the Secretary of the Treasury certain powers to perform CFPB functions until a Director is appointed.
    * There are two potential interpretations of the CFP Act's provisions regarding the powers of a recess appointed CFPB Director.
    * Interpreting the CFP Act to restrict a recess appointee's authority may raise separation of powers concerns, which a reviewing court would likely seek to avoid.
</summary>

<summary>
* The expedited removal process was established by Congress in 1996 through the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act (IIRIRA)
    * It allows for the summary removal of certain arriving aliens without a hearing or further review
* The expedited removal process has been gradually expanded by the immigration agencies over the years
    * Initially, it was limited to arriving aliens at ports of entry
    * It was later expanded to include aliens who arrived in the U.S. by sea and those apprehended within 100 miles of the border within 14 days of entry
* The expedited removal process has faced legal challenges, but courts have largely upheld its constitutionality
    * Courts have dismissed challenges for lack of jurisdiction, citing the limited judicial review available for expedited removal orders
* The expedited removal statute gives the Secretary of Homeland Security the authority to further expand the process to cover additional categories of aliens
    * This potential expansion has raised concerns about the due process rights of aliens already present in the U.S.
</summary>

<summary>
* The legal framework for congressional redistricting involves constitutional and federal statutory requirements, as well as case law interpretations:
    * The Supreme Court has interpreted the Constitution to require that each congressional district within a state contain approximately the same population, known as the "one person, one vote" standard.
    * Congressional district boundaries in every state are required to comply with Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, which prohibits any voting practice that results in the denial or abridgement of the right to vote based on race, color, or membership in a language minority.
</summary>

<summary>
• Severe fire seasons in the past decade have prompted substantial debate and proposals related to fire protection programs and funding.
    • President Clinton proposed a new National Fire Plan in 2000 to increase funding to protect federal, state, and private lands.
    • President Bush proposed a Healthy Forests Initiative in 2002 to expedite fuel reduction on federal lands.
• Congress has enacted several laws to address wildfire management, including the Healthy Forests Restoration Act in 2003 and the Federal Land Assistance, Management, and Enhancement (FLAME) Act in 2009.
• Federal wildfire funding has continued at relatively high levels since 2000, constituting a substantial portion of land management agency budgets.
• Federal wildfire management programs can be categorized into three groups:
    • Protection of federal lands
    • Assistance for protection of non-federal lands
    • Other fire-related expenditures, such as research and facility maintenance
• The high costs of firefighting continue to attract attention, with concerns about the effects on other agency programs and the need for better cost control and accountability.
• Fuel reduction efforts have increased since the mid-1990s, but the annual treatment acreage appears to have stabilized at less than 3 million acres annually, which is less than 1% of federal lands.
• The appropriate federal role in fire protection of non-federal lands and structures, as well as post-fire rehabilitation, continue to be debated.
</summary>

<summary>
• Current state of Social Security coverage for state and local government employees
    • About 27.5% of state and local government employees (6.6 million) are not covered by Social Security
    • Coverage rates vary significantly across states, with some states having less than 5% of employees covered
• Proposals for mandatory Social Security coverage of newly hired state and local government employees
    • Recommended by recent deficit reduction groups to increase the universality of the program
    • Projected to have a net positive effect on the Social Security Trust Funds
• Potential advantages of mandatory Social Security coverage
    • Simplify retirement planning and benefit coordination for workers
    • Provide better benefit protections through dependents' and survivors' benefits
    • Address the underfunding of state and local pension plans
• Potential disadvantages of mandatory Social Security coverage
    • States and localities may reduce existing pension benefits to keep overall costs down
    • Higher-wage workers may receive lower replacement rates under Social Security
    • Concerns about the impact on specialized public pension plans for certain occupations
• Administrative and legal considerations
    • Significant administrative burdens for state and local governments
    • Potential legal challenges, though likely to be upheld under current Supreme Court decisions
</summary>

<summary>
* Trade Adjustment Assistance for Workers (TAA) provides federal assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to foreign competition
    * TAA provides funding for training, reemployment services, and income support while a worker is enrolled in training
    * TAA is jointly administered by the federal government and the states, with the federal government providing funding
    * TAA eligibility is a two-stage process, with a group of workers first petitioning the Department of Labor for certification, and then individual workers applying for benefits
    * TAA benefits include training, reemployment services, income support, and a wage supplement program for workers aged 50 and over
    * TAA is subject to sequestration and has undergone several reauthorizations, with the most recent being the Trade Adjustment Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2015 (TAARA)
</summary>

<summary>
* The Federal Employees Dental and Vision Insurance Program (FEDVIP) was established in 2004 to provide supplemental dental and vision benefits to federal employees, Members of Congress, annuitants, and dependents.
    * FEDVIP offers four nationwide dental plans and three nationwide vision plans, with varying premiums and coverage options.
    * Individuals can enroll in FEDVIP during the annual open season, and coverage is primary to any dental or vision benefits provided by their Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) plan.
</summary>

<summary>
* The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (ARRA) provided $17.15 billion in supplemental funding for biomedical research, public health, and other health-related programs within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).
    * ARRA funds were designated as emergency supplemental appropriations for FY2009 and were to remain available for obligation through the end of FY2010.
* ARRA provided funding for various HHS agencies and offices, including:
    * $2 billion to the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) for grants to health centers
    * $10.4 billion to the National Institutes of Health (NIH) for biomedical research and extramural research facilities
    * $1.1 billion to the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) for comparative effectiveness research
    * $2 billion to the Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ONC) to fund activities and grant programs authorized by the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act
    * $1 billion to the Secretary for a Prevention and Wellness Fund
    * $500 million to the Indian Health Service (IHS) for health facilities-related activities and health information technology
* ARRA included requirements for transparency and accountability in the use of funds, including the submission of implementation plans, quarterly reports by grant recipients, and the posting of information on agency websites.
* The HITECH Act, incorporated in ARRA, aimed to promote the widespread adoption of health information technology (HIT) and included provisions for grant programs, HIT incentive payments under Medicare and Medicaid, and privacy and security standards.
* ARRA funds were used to support a variety of activities, including the construction and renovation of health centers, the recruitment and placement of health professionals, the development of comparative effectiveness research, and the implementation of HIT infrastructure and programs.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Livestock Mandatory Reporting Act (LMR) requires meat packers to report prices and other information on purchases of cattle, hogs, lamb, boxed beef, wholesale pork, and lamb carcasses and boxed lamb to the USDA.
    • The act was first enacted in 1999 and has been reauthorized several times, most recently in 2015 until 2020.
    • The act was enacted to provide accurate and objective market information to all buyers and sellers, as the livestock industry had undergone changes such as increased concentration and more vertical integration.
    • The act mandates price reporting for live cattle, boxed beef, and live swine, and allows USDA to establish mandatory price reporting for lamb sales.
    • The implementation of mandatory reporting did not affect the continuation of the AMS voluntary price-reporting program.
• The 2015 reauthorization of LMR included several changes:
    • It established a new negotiated formula purchase reporting category for swine.
    • It revised the definitions for lamb importers and lamb packers.
    • It required USDA to conduct a study of the price-reporting program for cattle, swine, and lamb.
    • The provision to deem mandatory reporting an "essential" service was not included in the final bill.
    • The cattle industry did not propose any changes to cattle LMR requirements, but the swine and lamb industries proposed changes that were incorporated into the reauthorization.
• The LMR law requires that price reporting be confidential to protect the identity of packers and contracts and proprietary business information.
    • AMS has adopted confidentiality guidelines to address data gaps.
    • AMS publishes a variety of daily and weekly reports under LMR, which covers a significant portion of livestock slaughter and meat production.
    • AMS enforces LMR through audits and can issue fines for non-compliance.
</summary>

<summary>
* Indictment or conviction of a felony does not directly affect a sitting U.S. Senator's congressional status or service, but may lead to internal party disciplinary actions.
    * Members do not automatically forfeit their offices upon conviction of a crime, except for certain treasonous conduct.
* Conviction of certain crimes may subject Senators to internal legislative disciplinary proceedings, including censure or expulsion.
    * Expulsion does not result in the forfeiture or loss of one's federal pension, but conviction of certain crimes may lead to such forfeiture.
* The Constitution does not provide for the recall of U.S. officials, and states cannot unilaterally change the length or number of terms of federal offices.
* Indictment or conviction of a crime is not a constitutional bar for eligibility to be elected or reelected as a Member of Congress, except for a conviction for treasonous conduct.
    * A congressional censure or expulsion does not act as a permanent disability to hold congressional office in the future.
</summary>

<summary>
* Overview of Forestlands in the United States
    * 766 million acres of forestlands, mostly privately owned (58%)
    * Federal government has numerous programs to support forest management on private and public forests
    * Programs administered by the Forest Service (FS) in the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
* History of Forestry Assistance Programs
    * Initial efforts began in 1881 with the creation of the USDA Division of Forestry
    * Forestry assistance and research programs grew over time, leading to the establishment of the USDA Forest Service in 1905
    * Congress has authorized specific forestry assistance programs, including the Clarke-McNary Act of 1924 and the Cooperative Forestry Assistance Act of 1978
* State Forest Action Plans and Coordination
    * States must prepare a State Forest Action Plan to be eligible for most forestry assistance programs
    * Plans include assessments of forest resource conditions, threats, and strategies to address them
    * State Forest Stewardship Coordination Committees provide recommendations on program priorities and plan development
* Types of Forestry Assistance
    * Technical assistance: Guidance, training, data, and information sharing
    * Financial assistance: Formula or competitive grants, cost-sharing
* Funding for Forestry Assistance Programs
    * Funding has declined over the past 15 years, both in real and constant dollars
    * Programs are funded through the FS's State and Private Forestry (SPF) account
    * Administration has proposed eliminating funding for some programs in recent years
* Repealed and Unfunded Programs
    * Some programs have been repealed by previous farm bills or gone unfunded by Congress
    * Activities from these programs may continue through other authorizations or funding sources
* Other Federal Forestry Assistance Programs
    * USDA Farm Services Agency and Natural Resources Conservation Service administer additional forestry programs
    * Department of the Interior also has a community assistance program for wildfire mitigation
</summary>

<summary>
* Transnational organized crime groups flourish in Burma, trafficking contraband that includes drugs, humans, guns, wildlife, gems, and timber.
    * Transnational crime is highly profitable, generating several billion dollars each year.
    * Corruption among officials in Burma's ruling military junta facilitates trafficking and provides immunity from law enforcement.
* Burma's long borders and difficult terrain, as well as continuing ethnic tensions, contribute to the presence of "ungoverned spaces" that enable transnational crime.
    * Congress has long been active in U.S. policy toward Burma, including imposing sanctions and strengthening unilateral sanctions.
    * The 111th Congress may continue its oversight of U.S. policy toward Burma, including the country's role in criminal activity.
* Various armed groups, including the United Wa State Army (UWSA), Shan State Army-South (SSA-S), and others, have criminal networks that stretch across the region.
    * These groups are linked to past or ongoing ethnic insurgencies and remain nearly immune from government interference due to widespread collusion with junta officials.
* Burma is the world's second-largest producer of illicit opium, and a significant producer of methamphetamine and other synthetic drugs.
    * Opium production is shifting to areas controlled by other cease-fire ethnic groups and the Tatmadaw, who tax the farmers and traders.
    * Burma's rise in synthetic drug production is partly a consequence of the UWSA's commitment to ban opium poppy cultivation.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) has had a significant impact on federal mandatory spending, primarily for expanding health insurance coverage.
    * The ACA has appropriated over $100 billion in mandatory funds for various programs and activities, including:
        * $40 billion for the State Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP)
        * $15 billion for the Prevention and Public Health Fund (PPHF)
        * $11 billion for the Community Health Center Fund (CHCF)
    * While most of the ACA's mandatory appropriations were temporary, Congress has extended funding for several programs, including:
        * Health centers (CHCF funding)
        * National Health Service Corps (CHCF funding)
        * Maternal, infant, and early childhood home visiting program
    * The ACA's mandatory spending is subject to sequestration, with some exceptions, under the Budget Control Act of 2011.
</summary>

<summary>
• Concerns about the increased presence of foreign students in graduate science and engineering programs and the scientific workforce
    • Enrollment of U.S. citizens in these programs has not kept pace with that of foreign students
    • Foreign students use U.S. graduate education programs as stepping stones to immigration
    • Approximately 56% of foreign doctorate degree earners on temporary visas remain in the U.S., with many becoming citizens
• Debate on the effects of foreign students in graduate programs
    • Some argue that U.S. universities and industry benefit from foreign talent
    • Others claim that U.S. workers are adversely affected by the entry of foreign scientists and engineers
    • Minority communities argue that there is a disparity in access to graduate education and resources
• Legislation and policies related to foreign students and workers
    • The H-1B visa program has been expanded and modified over time
    • Efforts to track and monitor foreign students and researchers have faced challenges
• Proposals for immigration reform and attracting foreign talent
    • Comprehensive immigration reform bills have been introduced
    • Bills aim to attract foreign students in scientific and technical disciplines
• Ongoing debate and concerns about the balance between the needs of the scientific community and the interests of U.S. workers
</summary>

<summary>
• The U.S. Department of Energy's (DOE) Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy (EERE) is funded through the annual Energy and Water Development (E&W) Appropriations bill.
	• EERE supports research, development, and implementation of renewable energy and energy efficiency technologies.
• The President's FY2018 budget request for EERE is a 70% decrease from FY2017 levels, focusing on early-stage R&D.
	• The request would eliminate the Weatherization Assistance Program and the State Energy Program.
• The House and Senate appropriations bills would provide more funding for EERE than the President's request, supporting later-stage R&D and deployment.
	• The House bill would provide $1.1 billion for EERE, while the Senate bill would provide $1.9 billion.
• Both bills would continue to fund the Weatherization Assistance Program and the State Energy Program.
• The House bill reflects a shift towards early-stage R&D, while the Senate bill affirms the importance of both development and deployment of energy efficiency and renewable energy technologies.
• Key differences between the House and Senate bills include funding levels for specific EERE offices and programs, as well as support for certain initiatives and hubs.
</summary>

<summary>
* Cryptocurrencies are digital currencies that use a decentralized network to validate transactions, rather than a centralized intermediary like a bank.
    * Cryptocurrencies have the potential to provide benefits, such as reduced costs and increased privacy, compared to traditional payment systems.
    * However, cryptocurrencies face challenges to widespread adoption, including price volatility, limited scalability, and lack of consumer protections.
    * Policymakers are grappling with issues related to cryptocurrencies, such as their potential use in criminal activities and their impact on monetary policy.
* The use of cryptocurrencies as money is still quite limited compared to traditional payment systems.
    * The number of Bitcoin transactions per day is a small fraction of the transactions processed by established payment systems.
    * Cryptocurrencies' price volatility undermines their ability to serve as a unit of account and store of value.
    * The scalability and energy consumption of cryptocurrency networks are also concerns.
* Cryptocurrencies may provide benefits, such as reduced costs and increased privacy, compared to traditional payment systems.
    * Cryptocurrencies could be especially beneficial for international money transfers, which often involve multiple intermediaries.
    * Cryptocurrencies may appeal to individuals who mistrust traditional financial institutions or government-backed currencies.
    * However, the extent to which these potential benefits will be realized is uncertain.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Protecting Employees and Retirees in Business Bankruptcies Act of 2007 (H.R. 3652) proposes several changes to Section 1113 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, which governs the rejection of collective bargaining agreements (CBAs) in chapter 11 bankruptcies.
    * The bill would limit the duration of modifications to CBAs to no more than two years and require that the proposed modifications be the minimum savings necessary for the debtor to successfully reorganize.
    * The bill would establish a presumption that the debtor has overly burdened the labor group compared to other groups, including management, if the debtor has implemented certain incentive pay or bonus programs during the bankruptcy or within 180 days prior.
    * The bill would allow labor groups to strike or engage in other "self-help" methods in response to court-ordered modifications or rejection of a CBA, which could jeopardize the debtor company's ability to reorganize.
</summary>

<summary>
* The report discusses appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2016, specifically the components included in the first title of the homeland security appropriations bill.
    * The report provides an overview of the Administration's FY2016 request, the appropriations proposed by Congress, and the enacted appropriations.
    * The report includes information on provisions throughout the proposed bills and reports that directly affect these functions.
* The report covers the following DHS components:
    * Office of the Secretary and Executive Management (OSEM)
    * Office of the Under Secretary for Management (USM)
    * Office of the Chief Financial Officer (OCFO)
    * Office of the Chief Information Officer (OCIO)
    * Analysis and Operations (A&O)
    * Office of Inspector General (OIG)
* The report discusses several issues related to departmental management and administration, including:
    * Acquisition matters and the implementation of a common appropriations structure
    * The DHS headquarters consolidation project at St. Elizabeths
* The report provides detailed funding information for each component, including the Administration's request, the amounts proposed by the Senate and House, and the enacted appropriations.
* The report also discusses congressional oversight and reporting requirements related to these DHS components and their activities.
* The report highlights the importance of financial management, IT modernization, and interoperable communications within the department.
* The report notes the role of the OIG in providing independent oversight and addressing waste, fraud, and abuse within DHS.
* The report provides context and analysis on the appropriations process and budgetary concepts relevant to the DHS appropriations.
</summary>

<summary>
• The distinction between net job loss and gross job loss is important for understanding the labor market dynamics.
    • Gross job loss is the total number of jobs eliminated by contracting firms, while net job loss is the result of greater gross job loss than gross job gains.
    • Gross job loss is a normal part of a functioning market economy and is caused by changes in tastes, technology, and comparative advantage, but is often offset by gross job gains.
• Factors such as trade, trade deficits, offshore outsourcing, and economic restructuring cause gross job loss but do not typically cause net job loss.
    • The exception is economic downturns, which are the only factor that causes both gross and net job loss.
• Public policies can be justified to protect workers against the risks posed by gross job loss, such as through unemployment insurance, but should be balanced with maintaining market dynamism.
    • Policies that impede gross job loss can have high efficiency costs and reduce gross job gains.
</summary>

<summary>
* U.S.-Japan Relations
    * Shinzo Abe has been Japan's prime minister since 2012 and has extended his party's term limits
    * Abe's foreign policy has displayed elements of both power politics and an emphasis on democratic values, international laws, and norms
    * Japan's relations with South Korea remain precarious due to historical grievances, particularly over the "comfort women" issue
    * The U.S.-Japan alliance remains a key anchor of U.S. security in Asia, with Japan providing advanced military assets and hosting a significant U.S. military presence
    * Japan's economy has faced stagnation for decades, but Abe's "Abenomics" program has aimed to revive growth through monetary stimulus, fiscal stimulus, and structural reforms
    * Trade tensions have emerged between the U.S. and Japan, with the Trump administration imposing tariffs on Japanese imports and seeking new bilateral trade negotiations
</summary>

<summary>
* Overview of Noncitizen Detention
    * Aliens can be detained while awaiting removal determination
    * Majority of detainees held in state/local prisons or contract facilities
    * Average daily detained population around 33,000 in over 300 facilities
* Medical Care for Detainees
    * ICE's National Detention Standards outline medical care requirements
    * Division of Immigrant Health Services (DIHS) responsible for health care
    * Detainees receive initial screening, physical exam, and mental health evaluation
    * Detainees have access to sick call and emergency dental treatment
    * Concerns about adherence to standards and adequacy of covered services
* Oversight and Reporting
    * ICE conducts annual inspections and has on-site quality assurance inspectors
    * Reports of inadequate oversight and identification of problems
    * Debate on using detainee deaths as a measure of care quality
</summary>

<summary>
• The Millennium Challenge Account (MCA) is a new U.S. foreign aid initiative aimed at promoting economic growth and reducing poverty in developing countries that demonstrate a commitment to good governance, economic freedom, and investing in people.
    • The MCA will be managed by a new government entity, the Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC), which will be overseen by a Board of Directors chaired by the Secretary of State.
    • The MCA will provide assistance to eligible countries based on their performance on 16 policy indicators, with a focus on results-based programs designed by the recipient countries.
• Key issues surrounding the MCA include:
    • Eligibility criteria and the inclusion of low-middle income countries
    • The selection of performance indicators and the use of a "hurdles" approach
    • The relationship between the MCA and existing U.S. foreign aid programs, particularly USAID
• The MCA authorizing legislation provides the executive branch with significant flexibility in implementing the initiative, while also establishing some congressional oversight mechanisms.
    • The legislation allows for a range of program types and beneficiaries, but prohibits certain activities such as military support or financing of abortions.
</summary>

<summary>
* The 112th Congress is considering an omnibus farm bill that will establish the direction of agricultural policy for the next several years.
    * The Senate Agriculture Committee approved its version of the 2012 omnibus farm bill on April 26, 2012 (S. 3240), and the House Agriculture Committee completed markup of its version of the farm bill (H.R. 6083) on July 11, 2012.
    * The bills would reshape the structure of farm commodity support, expand crop insurance coverage, consolidate conservation programs, revise the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, and extend authority to appropriate funds for many U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) discretionary programs through FY2017.
    * The Senate-passed farm bill (S. 3240) would reduce spending by $23.1 billion (2.3%), and the House Agriculture Committee-reported bill (H.R. 6083) would reduce it by $35.1 billion (-3.5%).
</summary>

<summary>
• Inland waterways are a significant component of the nation's marine transportation system, carrying approximately one-sixth of the national volume of intercity cargo on 25,000 miles of commercially active inland and intracoastal waterways.
    • The Inland Waterway System (IWS) is managed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and is funded through a combination of federal appropriations and user fees.
    • The current revenue source, a fuel tax, is insufficient to cover the non-federal costs of major capital expenditures on inland waterways, resulting in federal taxpayers covering more than half of these costs.
• Several proposals have been made to address the financing issues of the Inland Waterways Trust Fund (IWTF), including:
    • The Inland Waterways Users Board (IWUB) proposal to increase the fuel tax and shift more costs to the federal government.
    • The Obama Administration's proposal to institute a new user fee system in addition to the fuel tax.
</summary>

<summary>
• Legislative Options for Congressional Commemoratives
    • Naming federal buildings, including post offices
    • Designing postage stamps
    • Minting commemorative coins
    • Awarding Congressional Gold Medals
• Nonlegislative Options for Congressional Commemoratives
    • Sending certificates of recognition
    • Making floor speeches
    • Ordering flags flown over the Capitol Building
</summary>

<summary>
• The America COMPETES Reauthorization Act of 2010 (COMPETES 2010) was designed to invest in innovation through research and development and improve the competitiveness of the United States.
    • COMPETES 2010 authorized approximately $45.5 billion in funding between FY2010 and FY2013 for federal research in the physical sciences and engineering, STEM education, and other related programs.
• The President's FY2013 budget request sought increased funding for the "doubling path" accounts (NSF, NIST core laboratories and construction accounts, and DOE Office of Science) but included support for few COMPETES 2010 authorized STEM education programs.
    • Congressional appropriations for COMPETES 2010-related agencies in FY2013 were generally below FY2010 levels, with only the NIST core laboratory account higher in FY2013 than in FY2010.
• The COMPETES acts were designed to improve the competitive position of the United States by fostering scientific and technological innovation, but there is some opposition to the fundamental assumptions and high costs of the policies.
    • While there is widespread support for the innovation policy approach embodied in the COMPETES acts, some analysts dispute the assumptions behind the policies or prefer alternative policy tools.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Lacey Act was amended in 2008 to address illegal logging and the trade of plants and plant products
    * The amendments made it unlawful to import, export, transport, sell, receive, acquire, or purchase any plant taken, possessed, transported, or sold in violation of any law, treaty, or regulation of the United States or in violation of any Indian tribal law
    * The amendments also require importers of all covered plants and plant products to submit an import declaration to U.S. Customs and Border Protection at the time of importation
    * The primary aims of the 2008 amendments were to reduce illegal logging and to increase the value of U.S. wood exports
* Several policy issues are associated with the 2008 amendments
    * Some question why U.S. importers should be held responsible for violations of foreign law
    * The declaration requirements for plants and plant products are controversial
        * Some contend that the declaration requirements are a burden and difficult to comply with
        * Proponents of the declaration requirements contend that they are necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of the Lacey Act
    * The exercise of "due care" to determine if imported plants or plant products were legally harvested, processed, and exported is a key issue
        * Establishing a process for exercising due care has been proposed to clarify guidelines
        * Potential drawbacks include determining the level of reliability for verifying timber practices in foreign countries
* Potential legislative and regulatory options have been proposed to address the issues
    * Changes to the implementation of the Lacey Act through regulations have been suggested
    * Removing violations of foreign laws from the Lacey Act has been proposed
    * Strengthening existing federal programs aimed at reducing illegal logging in foreign countries has been suggested as a way to make compliance with the Lacey Act easier
</summary>

<summary>
* Farming is a cyclical business with exaggerated price swings that are destabilizing
    * Farmers respond to high prices by boosting output, but are not quick to cut back production when prices drop
    * Contributing factors include weather, export demand, currency exchange rate fluctuations, and farm support and export subsidy programs of foreign competitors
    * U.S. producers have asked for and received federal intervention, including various forms of counter-cyclical assistance, to support their commodity prices and incomes for nearly the past 70 years
* The 1996 Farm Bill replaced target price deficiency payments with fixed production flexibility contract (PFC) payments
    * PFC payments were not linked to either current production or prices, and were intended to cause the marketplace rather than subsidies to guide farmers' production choices
    * The 1996 law continued another form of counter-cyclical support: marketing assistance loans
    * By the late 1990s, major commodity prices declined even more than expected, and Congress determined that the "safety net" provided by the 1996 FAIR Act was inadequate
* The 2002 Farm Bill (FSRIA) provides new long-term counter-cyclical support for grains and cotton, by restoring target prices and deficiency payments
    * Fixed payments and target price deficiency payments will be paid on 85% of each farm's base production
    * The new counter-cyclical program is not contingent upon acreage reduction program rules, and payments are based upon historical, not current, production
    * The new law also brings soybeans and the minor oilseeds fully under the support program rules that apply to grains and cotton, and redesigns peanut support to operate like that for grains, oilseeds, and cotton
* The new counter-cyclical assistance in the 2002 law focuses on the "major" commodities, leaving much of U.S. agriculture ineligible for such payments
    * This raises questions of equity among commodities and the potential for distorting production towards items that might receive more support
    * Extending such aid to more commodities would have increased federal costs or reduced assistance levels for the major commodities
    * Not all commodity groups sought such aid, with some opposing most forms of direct assistance, counter-cyclical or otherwise
</summary>

<summary>
• U.S.-Vietnam nuclear cooperation agreement
    • Signed in May 2014 under Section 123 of the Atomic Energy Act
